displaytitle: Christ Wearing the Crown of Thorns, with a Medallion of the Trinity
medium: Pen and brown ink over black chalk, on light brown laid paper
creditline: Gift of Joseph F. McCrindle in honor of Allen Rosenbaum
signed: Signed in brown ink, lower left: Passerotto B

titles.title: Christ Wearing the Crown of Thorns, with a Medallion of the Trinity

makers.displaymaker: Bartolomeo Passarotti, 1529–1592; born and died Bologna, Italy

texts.textentryhtml: Together with its pendant, a head of the Virgin Mary (private collection, New York), this monumental sheet once belonged to Passarotti’s friend and patron, the Dominican polymath Egnazio Danti, who praised the artist as one of the greatest luminaries of the “arte del disegno” and singled out his exceptional penwork. In addition to being inspired by Michelangelo’s idealized heads, the artist cleverly adapted medallions of Roman emperors to a devotional purpose. Here, he simultaneously shows both views of a religious medallion, privileging its principal side, or obverse, in the larger, bust-size portrait. The high degree of finish, together with Passarotti’s signature, indicates that these drawings (perhaps once on the same sheet of paper) were commissioned by Danti or given to him as a token of friendship.

Egnazio Danti (1536–1586); Benno Geiger, London; sale, Sotheby’s, London, December 7–10, 1920, lot 213 (See reference Bib. 4842); J. Isaacs, London; Christopher Powney; Joseph F. McCrindle, New York and Princeton.;
